function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Small sample size in New York may not be representative of the entire New York City area or other cities in the U.S.","Impact":"Limited generalizability of study findings to other populations and locations.","Mitigation":"Conducting larger-scale studies with representative samples from diverse populations and locations.","Technologies":"Data collection technologies for large-scale studies, statistical analysis tools for diverse datasets.","People":"Research participants, policymakers, and public health officials.","Owner":"Research institutions, government agencies, and public health organizations."},{"Description":"Lack of consideration for cultural differences in social distancing, energy burden, access to technology, and healthy built-home environments may lead to biased findings.","Impact":"Findings may not accurately reflect the energy use patterns and risk factors for different cultural groups.","Mitigation":"Incorporating cultural diversity in study design, data collection, and analysis, and consulting with experts from diverse cultural backgrounds.","Technologies":"Cultural competency training for researchers, ethnographic research methods, and culturally sensitive survey tools.","People":"Minority and marginalized communities, researchers, and policymakers.","Owner":"Research institutions, community organizations, and policymakers."},{"Description":"Failure to address social- psychological factors such as perceived fairness and social networks could result in overlooking important risk factors for disease propagation.","Impact":"Underestimation of the influence of social-psychological factors on disease transmission and public health interventions.","Mitigation":"Incorporating social-psychological assessments in the study design, using qualitative research methods to explore these factors, and collaborating with social and behavioral scientists.","Technologies":"Social network analysis tools, qualitative data analysis software, and surveys assessing social-psychological variables.","People":"Public health officials, behavioral scientists, community leaders, and researchers.","Owner":"Public health organizations, academic institutions, and community-based organizations."}]}
